line: S ample 1.The sample below is an opening paragraph from a student essay on the development of
label: paragraph

line: entertainment media. In it, she describes TV-watching in her family to make a point about how
label: paragraph

line: central TV was as a form of entertainment in the 60’s.
label: paragraph

line: (1) As I was growing up in the 60’s, television was the only entertainment my
label: paragraph

line: family knew of the electronic sort. (2) The 7 o’clock nightly news was such an
label: paragraph

line: important part of our family that my dad knocked a wall down and built a huge
label: paragraph

line: cabinet in its place just to accommodate our 19-inch black and white. (3) No one
label: paragraph

line: was allowed to talk or make a sound when the television was on; all eyes were
label: paragraph

line: glued to the moving and flickering image. The box commanded absolute
label: paragraph

line: respect.(4) In the daytime, “the television needs its rest” my mother would say, as
label: paragraph

line: she patted its pseudo-wooden top and covered it with a doilie she had made
label: paragraph

line: herself. (5)There is no doubt that TV was as central to our lives as it was to the
label: paragraph

line: lives of all our friends during that period. (adapted from an essay by Angeline
label: paragraph

line: Chan, used with permission.)
label: paragraph

line: Notice the writer’s use of action verbs (knocked, glued) and her use of sensory words (19- inch,
label: paragraph

line: black and white, huge, talk, sound, flickering)) to paint a picture of the scene in her living room.
label: paragraph

line: In the final sentence, she states the main point of the paragraph: that TV was central in families’
label: paragraph

line: lives during the 60’s. The appearance of a topic sentence at the end of a paragraph, rather than at
label: paragraph

line: the beginning is common in descriptive paragraphs, and it works well for this kind of
label: paragraph

line: development.

line: S ample 2. This paragraph is a student’s response to an assignment to describe a place of
label: paragraph

line: personal importance or beauty:
label: paragraph

line: (1) The trail, perching precariously 500 feet above the roaring surf and then
label: paragraph

line: dipping effortlessly into dark lush valleys, snakes its way along the fluted
label: paragraph

line: coastline. (2) From a distance, it is hard to believe there would be any way to
label: paragraph

line: traverse the cliffs that dip like fingers into the frothing Pacific. (3)The first half of
label: paragraph

line: the trail is densely overgrown, and the air is dripping with the aroma of over ripe
label: paragraph

line: guava. Waterfalls and streams cascade unceasingly down along the trail from
label: paragraph

line: Mount Waialeale, the wettest spot on earth. (4) Vegetation grows thickly on the
label: paragraph

line: near vertical slopes above and below the trail, lending a sense of false security to
label: paragraph

line: the path, which at its widest measures ten feet across. (5)The landscape on the
label: paragraph

line: second half of the trail, the leeward side, changes dramatically from jungle to
label: paragraph

line: semi-arid desert. (6)Now, the cliffs are bare rock, and a three-foot wide ledge is
label: paragraph

line: all that protects the wary hiker from the black shoreline below.(7) Nevertheless,
label: paragraph

line: the white sand beach that marks the end of the trail is more than ample reward
label: paragraph

line: for the dangers survived.(8) The colors of this last valley, the Kalalau Valley, are
label: paragraph

line: a vivid red and green against a cloudless blue sky. (9)This, however, is not the
label: paragraph

line: end of the trip. The only trail out is the trail in. Not for the faint of heart, the
label: paragraph

line: Kalalua Trail on Kauai’s north shore is eleven miles of rugged adventure. (from
label: paragraph

line: an essay by Noreen Edgar, used with permission)
label: paragraph

line: This writer, too, makes liberal use of sense words (roaring, dark, lush, thickly etc.) and vivid
label: paragraph

line: action verbs (snakes, traverse, cascade). In addition, she uses a spatial arrangement that moves
label: paragraph

line: much in the way a hiker might, from a distant view, to a description of the first half of the trail,
label: paragraph

line: and then to the second half. The topic sentence, (sentence 9) as in the first sample, is found at
label: paragraph

line: the end instead of the beginning of the paragraph.
